title: Honorific inscription for Clodia Falconilla
support: Marble plaque made up of nine joining fragments, of which both the top and the bottom are lost. Surface and back smooth and polished.

layout.p: Five lines of Latin text, in straight alignment and shifted toward the right, with a wider left margin.The letters in the first line, which is partially legible, are of slightly greater module than those in the following lines, and are more widely spaced. The last line – of which only parts of one or more letters are preserved (perhaps an A and and the left apex of a V; an M is also possible) are preserved – appears more centered, with both left and right margins wider.

handNote.lettering: Elegant square capital letters, slightly verticalized, with serifs. The O in l. 1 is square in shape compared to the O in the other lines; A has a vertical crossbar, P has an open loop. In l. 2, a triple nexus links the letters T, R, and I, with the I rising above. In l. 4, there is spacing between the words Sosius and Priscus. Comma-shaped punctuation marks appear in ll. 1 and 3. A damaged ivy leaf appears at the end of l. 1.

date._: Early 2nd century, mother of cos. 108 CE

provenanceFound._: Discovered by Guido Libertini during the excavation campaigns conducted starting in 1925, within the complex of spaces near the so-called former Barbagallo Mill, i.g. the area of the so-called "Edificio degli Augustales" , in a zone overlooking the Vallata Difesa, near the Church of the Crucifix. The contextual information is not very clear. Specifically, the author states that he found the inscription “a sei o sette metri più a nord del Mulino, [dove] si trovava un’ampia costruzione, una parte della quale, di forma rettangolare e non inferiore agli 11 m di lunghezza, era pavimentata in marmo e circondata, sembra, da una platea in pietra". Currently on display on the ground floor in the Antiquarium, Room III
